Award.AwardTitle: EAGER Self-Catalyzed Growth of Patterned GaAsSb and GaAsSbN Nanowires for Optoelectronic Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Science Foundation uses the Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) funding mechanism to support exploratory work in its early stages on untested, but potentially transformative, research ideas or approaches. This EAGER project was awarded as a result of the invitation in the Dear Colleague Letter NSF 16-080 to proposers from Historically Black Colleges and Universities to submit proposals that would strengthen research capacity of faculty at the institution. The project at North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University proposes a comprehensive investigation of the band gap engineering in a certain nanowire ensemble. The results of this project could have wide-ranging technological applications in security, quantum communications, photovoltaics and medical fields.

With better optical trapping features and a large aspect ratio facilitating radial strain relaxation, one-dimensional architecture of semiconductor nanowires (NWs) can be manipulated for a distinct combination of physical, electronic and optical properties. The focus of this project is geared towards comprehensive investigation of the band gap engineering in the patterned array of a GaAsSb and dilute nitride GaAsSbN nanowire ensemble, which is a potential candidate for implementation in next-generation tunable, high performance nanoscale sources and detectors spanning a significant portion of the short wave infrared region. This project's objective is to probe the effects of NW array pitch on the growth kinetics, structure, band gap engineering, and optical properties of patterned GaAsSb and GaAsSbN NWs on (111)Si grown by self-assisted molecular beam epitaxy. A variety of characterization techniques will be employed to investigate the role of the surfactant, Sb, and how it can be manipulated in NW array to accomplish the band gap engineering, independent tuning of the band gap, and optical characteristics to achieve the desired band gap with high optical performance. Further, incorporating a diluted amount of nitrogen to the GaAsSb alloy is known to exhibit distinct and favorable optoelectronic properties in thin films, though offset by the presence of point defects. The experimental work on both of the above alloys will be guided by finite difference time domain and finite element modeling simulations of the growth kinetics and optical characteristics, respectively.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Semiconductor nanowires (NWs) have stimulated considerable interest due to their one-dimensional architecture and high aspect ratio, enabling better stress-strain management, optical trapping,  and quantum confinements leading to unique optoelectronic properties. Commercialization of the NW-based electronic devices requires demonstration of scalability and reliable performance, which can be achieved by site-specific growth on pre-patterned substrates, as these enable independent tuning of the diameter and length. The intellectual merit of the HBCU EAGER project has been in advancing the fundamental understanding of the growth kinetics and bandgap engineering in patterned nanowires of GaAsSb and dilute nitride GaAsSbN. These are potential candidates for implementation in next-generation tunable, high-performance nanoscale sources, and detectors spanning a wavelength range from 1.0 um to 1.3 um wavelength region. The effects of NW array pitch on the growth kinetics, structure, bandgap engineering, and optical properties of patterned GaAsSb in both axial and core-shell configurations grown by self-assisted molecular beam epitaxy on (111) Si were investigated. The growth dependency on the pitch length was successfully modeled using semi-empirical mass conservation of the growth-species-based-model encompassing different material pathways of deposition in both the axial and core-shell configured GaAsSb NWs. Furthermore, the values of incorporation parameters extracted from this modeling can be used as a tool for the comparison of incorporated species and the composition thereof.

We have also demonstrated alloying GaAsSb with the dilute amount of N as another pathway for bandgap engineering. GaAsSbN NWs provided broader photoluminescence (PL) emission and also exhibited a slightly higher PL redshift of 75 meV as opposed to 40-50 meV observed in GaAsSb NWs, for pitch length variations from 200 nm to 1200 nm. Pitch-dependent axial and radial growth rates show a logistic sigmoidal growth trend, different from those commonly observed in other patterned non-nitride III-V NWs. The sigmoidal fitting provides further insight into the PL spectral shift arising from differences in Sb and N incorporations from pitch induced variation in secondary fluxes. Results indicate that sigmoidal fitting can be a potent tool for designing patterned NW arrays of optimal pitch length for dilute nitrides, and other highly mismatched alloys and heterostructures.

 The results of this research have wide-ranging technological applications in security, quantum communications, photovoltaics, and the medical arena.  The significant educational value associated with this program enabled attracting a Title III fellowship student, who actively participated in this project, leading to several conference presentations and culminating in a manuscript submitted for journal publication. Active undergraduate participation primarily from an underrepresented group led to video production of 3 minutes explaining the NW growth concept in a way that the general public can understand, that was displayed in ?2018 STEM for all Video Showcase?.
